sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a precipitation reaction
message_1: What is the standard enthalpy change of the precipitation reaction between silver nitrate (AgNO3) and potassium chloride (KCl) to form silver chloride (AgCl) and potassium nitrate (KNO3)? Given the balanced equation: AgNO3 + KCl --> AgCl + KNO3. The relevant standard heats of formation are: ∆Hf°(AgNO3) = -146.64 kJ/mol, ∆Hf°(KCl) = -436.21 kJ/mol, ∆Hf°(AgCl) = -127.01 kJ/mol, and ∆Hf°(KNO3) = -494.63 kJ/mol.
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change of the precipitation reaction, we can use the following equation:

∆H°(reaction) = Σ ∆Hf°(products) - Σ ∆Hf°(reactants)

For the given reaction, the standard heats of formation are:

∆Hf°(AgNO3) = -146.64 kJ/mol
∆Hf°(KCl) = -436.21 kJ/mol
∆Hf°(AgCl) = -127.01 kJ/mol
∆Hf°(KNO3) = -494.63 kJ/mol

Now, we can plug these values into the equation:

∆H°(reaction) = [(-127.01 kJ/mol) + (-494.63 kJ/mol)] - [(-146.64 kJ/mol) + (-436.21 kJ/mol)]

∆H°(reaction) = (-621.64 kJ/mol) - (-582.85 kJ/mol)

∆H°(reaction) = -38.79 kJ/mol

The standard enthalpy change of the precipitation reaction between silver nitrate and potassium chloride is -38.79 kJ/mol.
